options.text: It changes its course to a straighter path downhill

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The length of the meander is inversely proportional to the width of the stream

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary factor that determines the formation of meandering streams?

options.label: B
options.text: The soft soil on the plains

options.label: D
options.text: The natural tendency of a river to meander

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the difference in how students with fixed and growth mindsets approach school?

options.label: A
options.text: Students with fixed mindsets are more motivated and students with growth mindsets are less motivated.

options.label: B
options.text: Students with fixed mindsets have different goals in school.

options.label: C
options.text: Students with fixed mindsets are older than students with growth mindsets.

options.label: D
options.text: Students with fixed mindsets are less intelligent than students with growth mindsets.

multiple-choice.question: What do students with a growth mindset do when they don't understand something?

options.label: A
options.text: They avoid asking questions to preserve the image that they are smart.

options.label: B
options.text: They ask questions to learn and develop their intelligence.

options.label: C
options.text: They give up and move on.

options.label: D
options.text: They try to figure it out on their own.

multiple-choice.question: How do students with a fixed mindset view challenges or setbacks?

options.label: A
options.text: As opportunities to learn and develop their intelligence.

options.label: B
options.text: As a chance to prove their intelligence.

options.label: C
options.text: Negatively, thinking that it means they're not smart.

options.label: D
options.text: As a way to hide their lack of intelligence.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the result of students with a growth mindset trying harder in school, especially in the face of a challenge?

options.label: C
options.text: They get the same grades as students with a fixed mindset.

multiple-choice.question: What do students with a growth mindset think intelligence is like?

options.label: A
options.text: A fixed trait that you're born with.

options.label: B
options.text: A muscle that you can develop through effort and challenge.

options.label: C
options.text: A way to hide your lack of intelligence.

options.label: D
options.text: A way to prove your intelligence.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the relationship between students' disagreement with statements like "you can learn new things but you can't really change your basic intelligence" and their mindset?

options.label: A
options.text: The more they disagree, the more they have a fixed mindset.

options.label: B
options.text: The more they disagree, the more they have a growth mindset.

options.label: C
options.text: There is no relationship between their disagreement and their mindset.

options.label: D
options.text: The more they agree, the more they have a growth mindset.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal for students with a growth mindset in school?

options.label: A
options.text: To show how smart they are or hide how unintelligent they are.

options.label: B
options.text: To learn and develop their intelligence.

options.label: C
options.text: To make friends and have fun.

options.label: D
options.text: To get good grades and achieve academic success.

title: Vatican City Explained

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question

options.label: A
options.text: The Vatican City was established in 1929.

options.label: B
options.text: The Vatican City was established in 1945.

options.label: C
options.text: The Vatican City was established in 1963.

options.label: D
options.text: The Vatican City was established in 1989.

multiple-choice.question: Conceptual Question

options.label: A
options.text: The Holy See is a corporation and the Catholic Church is a country.

options.label: B
options.text: The Holy See is a country and the Catholic Church is a corporation.

options.label: C
options.text: The Holy See is a country and the Catholic Church is a religious organization.

options.label: D
options.text: D: The Holy See is a religious organization and the Catholic Church is a country.

multiple-choice.question: Application Question

options.label: A
options.text: If the King of Vatican City is also the Pope, he would have absolute power to make decisions for the country.

options.label: B
options.text: If the King of Vatican City is also the Pope, he would have limited power to make decisions for the country.

options.label: C
options.text: If the King of Vatican City is also the Pope, he would have no power to make decisions for the country.

options.label: D
options.text: If the King of Vatican City is also the Pope, he would have to consult with the Cardinals before making decisions for the country.

multiple-choice.question: Analytical Question

options.label: A
options.text: The King of Vatican City has absolute power because he is the CEO of the Holy See.

options.label: B
options.text: The King of Vatican City has absolute power because he is the head of the Catholic Church.

options.label: C
options.text: The King of Vatican City has absolute power because he is the head of the government of Vatican City.

options.label: D
options.text: The King of Vatican City has absolute power because he is the monarch of the country.

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question

options.label: A
options.text: Vatican City is a member of the United Nations.

options.label: B
options.text: Vatican City is not a member of the United Nations.

options.label: C
options.text: Vatican City is a member of the European Union.

options.label: D
options.text: Vatican City is not a member of the European Union.

multiple-choice.question: Conceptual Question

options.label: A
options.text: The Pope is the head of the government of Vatican City.

options.label: B
options.text: The King of Vatican City is the head of the government of Vatican City.

options.label: C
options.text: The Pope and the King of Vatican City are the same person.

options.label: D
options.text: The Pope and the King of Vatican City are two different people.

multiple-choice.question: Application Question

options.label: A
options.text: If the King of Vatican City appoints someone as a citizen, that person will have the right to vote in elections.

options.label: B
options.text: If the King of Vatican City appoints someone as a citizen, that person will have the right to work for the Pope.

options.label: C
options.text: If the King of Vatican City appoints someone as a citizen, that person will have the right to live in Vatican City.

options.label: D
options.text: If the King of Vatican City appoints someone as a citizen, that person will have the right to work for the government of Vatican City.

multiple-choice.question: Analytical Question

options.label: A
options.text: The reason the world cares about Vatican City is because of its large population.

options.label: B
options.text: The reason the world cares about Vatican City is because of its economic power.

options.label: C
options.text: The reason the world cares about Vatican City is because of its billion members of the Catholic Church.

options.label: D
options.text: The reason the world cares about Vatican City is because of its unique government.

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question

options.label: A
options.text: Vatican City has a permanent population of 500 citizens.

options.label: B
options.text: Vatican City has a permanent population of 5,000 citizens.

options.label: C
options.text: Vatican City has a permanent population of 50,000 citizens.

options.label: D
options.text: Vatican City has a permanent population of 500,000 citizens.

multiple-choice.question: Conceptual Question

options.label: A
options.text: Vatican City is a sovereign corporate headquarters that grants temporary citizenship to its managers.

options.label: B
options.text: Vatican City is a real city-state like Singapore.

options.label: C
options.text: Vatican City is a country that has a self-reproducing population of citizens.

options.label: D
options.text: Vatican City is a country that lacks a permanent population of citizens.

title: What happens when your DNA is damaged? - Monica Menesini

multiple-choice.question: How many DNA errors occur in the human body every day?
What is the primary function of DNA polymerase during DNA replication?
What is the process called when the enzyme DNA polymerase makes a mistake and brings in the wrong partner to pair with a base?
What is the main difference between homologous recombination and non-homologous end joining in repairing double strand breaks?

options.label: A
options.text: Homologous recombination uses a template, while non-homologous end joining does not

options.label: B
options.text: Homologous recombination is more accurate, while non-homologous end joining is less accurate

options.label: C
options.text: Homologous recombination is faster, while non-homologous end joining is slower

options.label: D
options.text: Homologous recombination is used for single strand breaks, while non-homologous end joining is used for double strand breaks

multiple-choice.question: What is the process called when a single base is damaged and can usually be fixed by a process called base excision repair?

What is the main purpose of mismatch repair?

options.label: C
options.text: To reduce the number of base mismatch errors

title: How misused modifiers can hurt your writing

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the grammatical mistake demonstrated in the example sentence "Thief robs town with world's largest chocolate bunny"?
What is the primary effect of a misplaced modifier on a sentence?

options.label: A
options.text: It adds clarity to the sentence

options.label: B
options.text: It makes the sentence more concise

options.label: C
options.text: It dramatically changes the meaning of the sentence

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on the sentence's meaning

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following sentences is an example of a dangling modifier?

options.label: A
options.text: "Having robbed the bank in record time, the thief was able to make off with the town's chocolate rabbit."

options.label: B
options.text: "The thief robbed the bank in record time and made off with the town's chocolate rabbit."

options.label: C
options.text: "Having robbed the bank in record time, it was possible to make off with the town's chocolate rabbit as well."

options.label: D
options.text: "The thief robbed the bank in record time, and it was possible to make off with the town's chocolate rabbit as well."

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for a modifier that is stuck between two things and could feasibly refer to either?
Which of the following sentences is an example of a squinting modifier?

options.label: A
options.text: "Robbers who steal chocolate bunnies rapidly attract the outrage of onlookers."

options.label: B
options.text: "Robbers who steal chocolate bunnies attract the outrage of onlookers rapidly."

options.label: C
options.text: "Robbers who steal chocolate bunnies quickly attract the outrage of onlookers."

options.label: D
options.text: "Robbers who steal chocolate bunnies attract the outrage of onlookers quickly."

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of a modifier in a sentence?

options.label: A
options.text: To add information about other parts of the sentence

options.label: B
options.text: To make the sentence more concise

options.label: C
options.text: To change the meaning of the sentence

options.label: D
options.text: To add emphasis to a particular word or phrase

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following sentences is a clear and grammatically correct example of a sentence with a modifier?

options.label: A
options.text: "Town with world's largest chocolate bunny robbed by thief."

options.label: B
options.text: "Thief robs town with world's largest chocolate bunny."

options.label: C
options.text: "Having robbed the bank in record time, it was possible to make off with the town's chocolate rabbit as well."

options.label: D
options.text: "Robbers who steal chocolate bunnies rapidly attract the outrage of onlookers."

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the process of rephrasing a sentence to make it clearer which part of the sentence a modifier is referring to?
Which of the following sentences is an example of a sentence with a misplaced modifier?

options.label: A
options.text: "Having robbed the bank in record time, the thief was able to make off with the town's chocolate rabbit."

options.label: B
options.text: "The thief robbed the bank in record time and made off with the town's chocolate rabbit."

options.label: C
options.text: "Having robbed the bank in record time, it was possible to make off with the town's chocolate rabbit as well."

options.label: D
options.text: "The thief robbed the bank in record time, and it was possible to make off with the town's chocolate rabbit as well."

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of using modifiers in a sentence?

options.label: A
options.text: To add complexity to the sentence

options.label: B
options.text: To make the sentence more concise

options.label: C
options.text: To avoid verbal ambiguity and make it clear which parts of the sentence modifiers belong to

options.label: D
options.text: To change the meaning of the sentence
